title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance and Nutrition Support to Conflict Affected Families in Borno State Phase 2

description.narrative:
5.2 million people in the NE are in need of emergency food aid (UNOCHA). Fluctuations of the Naira and ongoing inflation, have diminished purchasing power. This has hindered access to food, a priority need for vulnerable, conflict-affected HHs. 1.6 million people in Borno State are in IPC 3-5. This will increase to over 1.9 million people over the 2018 lean season (May - August), affected areas include Gubio LGA (IPC 3) and Magumeri LGA (IPC 4). Across Borno, malnutrition remains severe. A recent UNICEF survey shows rates for Central Borno at 10.3% MAM, 3.1% SAM.
This action will support conflict-affected IDPs, returnees and host community HHs to meet basic food and nutritional needs. CAFOD with Catholic Relief Services (CRS) and local partners NEYIF; JDPC, and FOMWAN will meet immediate survival needs of vulnerable HHs in Gubio and Magumeri. Building lessons learned from phase 1, this action will provide life-saving assistance to vulnerable HHs, using e-vouchers through a single Cash and Asset Transfer Management Platform providing essential food and NFis. In line with ECHO's objectives to (i) ensure populations affected by on-going armed conflicts receive humanitarian assistance and (ii) prevent and reduce severe malnutrition and excessive mortality of children under five, this action will support 32,500 individuals, or 6,500 HHs.
Nutrition screening, referral, and infant and young child feeding (IYCF) counselling will aim at improving the nutrition of acutely malnourished children under five. Trained community mobilizers (CMs) will conduct malnutrition screening of children under fives using MUAC screening. Those identified will be referred to clinics, with transportation and accompaniment provided as necessary. CMs will conduct follow up for all identified SAM and MAM cases, providing support and counseling on optimal IYCF practices. Follow-up continues regularly until they are no longer acutely malnourished (MUAC tape moves from red or orange to green).
